awd_abstract_narration:
The basic nature of encryption has always been all-or-nothing: anyone who is privy to the secret key can decode and recover the entire data; but, without the key, nothing can be revealed. In other words, the only useful action that could be performed on encrypted data was decryption using the secret key. In the modern world of cloud computing, we store much of our personal data in the cloud, and perform computations on them remotely. The numerous security concerns with cloud storage and computation raise a number of challenging questions: Can we encrypt data and run computations on it without decrypting? Can we encrypt programs and allow users to execute them without discovering any details about their internal operations, other than the eventual result? 

This project is dedicated to the study of the paradigm of computing on encrypted data and programs, and the design of fundamental cryptographic primitives underlying this broad goal. Specifically, it focuses on three major cryptographic primitives: (i) fully homomorphic encryption, which enables computations on encrypted data; (ii) functional encryption, which enables expressive access control; and (iii) program obfuscation, which lets us hide the structure of programs while preserving their functionality. The overarching goal is to develop constructions of these cryptographic primitives that achieve a high degree of efficiency, but also guarantee security under well-studied cryptographic assumptions. Towards this end, the project explores both software and hardware techniques, and the use of novel mathematical tools from algebra, geometry and number theory.

por.por_cntn:
The central goal of this project was to investigate cryptographic mechanisms for encrypted computations that protect the privacy of data and programs owned by individuals and organizations. Part of the project consisted of developing new methods for homomorphic encryption, a powerful way of computing on data while it stays encrypted; attribute-based, predicate and functional encryption, notions that enable fine-grained control of access to encrypted data; and program obfuscation, a method of encrypting programs that allows parties to run them on inputs and get (cleartext) outputs, but does not allow anyone to learn the inner workings of the program. In the process of developing these new encryption systems, the project also studied the fundamental mathematical and computational hardness assumptions on integer lattices that underlie their security. Finally, the contributions in this project run the gamut from new mathematical constructions to their practical applications.

In the area of homomorphic encryption, the project constructed a pure FHE scheme capable of evaluating arbitrary polynomial-size circuits, assuming the existence of an indistinguishability obfuscation (IO) scheme. All prior works required special "circular security" assumptions. 

In the area of attribute-based encryption (ABE), the project constructed the first arithmetic attribute-based encryption scheme. As a side-effect, this work solved the 30-year-old open problem of constructing garbled circuits whose size has only an additive overhead (over and above the size of the circuit itself). In addition, the garbled circuit had a reusability property. We then strengthened this to an attribute-hiding ABE scheme (also referred to as predicate encryption).

One of the major open problems in cryptography today is to construct a program obfuscation scheme (technically, indistinguishability obfuscation) from well-defined, standard, cryptographic assumptions. The project showed how to construct program obfuscation schemes from a weaker primitive called functional encryption. This work laid the technical pathway for much of the modern progress in program obfuscation. We also showed how to construct a functional encryption scheme from constant-degree multilinear maps together with local PRGs. This work has formed the basis of a flurry of followup work that showed that 3-linear maps, and even bilinear maps together with an exotic assumption, suffice.

Finally, the project resulted in the solution of a long-standing open problem in the field of information-theoretic cryptography by breaking the exponential barrier in the share size for general secret sharing schemes.

On the practical side, the project showed how to translate many of these works into practical instantiations and applications. We built a practical private database querying system called "Splinter". Splinter supports a variety of real SQL queries on databases of millions of records with sub-second end-to-end response time. We also built a system for encrypted neural network classification called "GAZELLE" which integrates the best of homomorphic encryption and traditional multiparty computation tools to construct protocols that achieve practical end-to-end runtimes. These works involved collaborations with hardware and security researchers and integrated ideas from multiple areas of computer science.

As part of the educational component of this project, the PI developed and taught two classes: the first on modern techniques for computing on encrypted data and the second on the mathematics of lattices with applications to cryptography. The lecture notes for both classes are available for free online. The PI was also involved in organizing several workshops that bring together researchers that work on lattices and on encrypted computing. This project has resulted in training graduate and undergraduate students to engage in original research. Indeed, much of the work reported above was led by graduate students. Finally, the PI has been an active organizer of the Charles River Crypto day that brings together cryptographers and security researchers in the Boston area two or three times a year for a day of talks and discussion on cutting edge topics in cryptography.
